prompt.p: A 37-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes for 20 years is seen with an erythematous non-tender left foot. On examination pus can be seen to be draining from the plantar surface of the second metatarsal head. She has a weak but palpable dorsalis pedis pulse. She is feverish with a temperature of 38.5 o C.
The most likely factor predisposing to the original ulceration is:

modalFeedback.p: Option D (Neuropathy) is Correct. The presence of the plantar ulceration strongly indicates that this is a classic neuropathic ulcer which has become secondarily infected.
Option A (Arterial insufficiency) is Incorrect. The presence of the dorsalis pedis pulse indicates that arterial insufficiency is not the cause.
Option B (Infection) is Incorrect. The presence of pus indicates a bacterial infection secondary to the original cause of the ulceration.
Option C (Insect bite) is Incorrect. This would be extremely unlikely.
Option E (Self-mutilation) is Incorrect. This would be extremely unlikely.
